headline: Make-Ahead Turkey Gravy
description: A make-ahead turkey gravy that frees up your time on Thanksgiving day! Roasted turkey wings provide tons of flavor to this rich, smooth gravy.

video.description: This turkey gravy recipe is perfect for Thanksgiving or any time of year. You can make it fresh to have with your holiday meal or ahead of time ands store it for later for up to 3 months in the freezer.
video.name: Make Ahead Turkey Gravy

name: Make-Ahead Turkey Gravy

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
Arrange turkey wings in a single layer in a large roasting pan; scatter onions over top.
Roast in the preheated oven until wings are browned, about 1 hour 15 minutes.
Transfer wings and onions to a 5-quart stockpot.
Add water to the roasting pan and stir, scraping up any brown bits on the bottom of the pan.
Pour water and pan scrapings into the stockpot.
Stir in 6 cups chicken broth, carrots, and thyme. Set over medium-high heat and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer, uncovered, for 1 1/2 hours.
Transfer wings to a cutting board and let sit until cool enough to handle. Pull off skin and meat. Discard skin and reserve meat for another use.
Pour contents of the stockpot through a large strainer into a 3-quart saucepan. Press on vegetables in the strainer to extract any remaining liquid; discard vegetables.
Skim and discard fat from the turkey broth, then bring to a gentle boil.
Whisk flour into the remaining 2 cups chicken broth in a bowl until smooth.
Gradually whisk flour mixture into the simmering turkey broth. Simmer, whisking occasionally, until gravy has thickened, 3 to 4 minutes. Stir in butter and pepper.
Serve immediately or pour into containers, cool, and refrigerate or freeze.

review.reviewBody: great idea and great recipe. I made a week in advance and put in the freezer.
If you like gravy with overwhelming flour taste, this is for you. Bleeckh.
THIS. RECIPE. IS. AWESOME. THANK YOU!!!!! This is the BEST gravy I have ever made in my life and I can’t wait to show it off tomorrow — SOOOO delicious. Thank you thank you thank you! :)

Fantastic!!! I made my roux with the reserved fat along with some chicken broth then used an emulsion blender to incorporate into the stock. We host 20 plus people on Thanksgiving & having enough gravy is always an issue…problem solved!

I made the recipe as written and I was a little disappointed. While the turkey wings smelled great cooking, the actual gravy was light and tasted mostly of onion. Perhaps a good back-up gravy? Not as meaty as Cook’s Illustrated Turkey gravy recipe.

Roasted four turkey wings with onions. Followed above directions. Beautiful dark color and flavor. Made about 8 cups plus drippings. This is the best make ahead recipe I've ever made. Saved me so much time stirring and standing over stove on Thanksgiving Day when I'd rather relax with family. Thank you!

I’ve been using this recipe for years! Obviously, it’s a great recipe and guide to start with and make any adjustments to suit your tastes. It’s so nice to have a few things to make in advance like this to make the day go easier for me. Thank you for sharing it! My family loves it!!!!

It is wonderful to make extra gravy ahead. I am from New Orleans and am used to making a roux, so I used both butter and fat from the pan and added flour that I sauteed until all the raw flavor of the flour is gone, and it was the color I was looking for. I also added a drizzle of olive oil and pats of butter on top of wings and onions before baking, as well as salt and pepper. To stock-pot, I added celery as well as carrots and bay leaf for flavor. It tasted very good, but recipe needed tweaking.

I was assigned to gravy for our annual Thanksgiving camping trip with 10 friends. Not wanting to try to make great gravy in a 5th wheel...I made this a week ahead of time... Super hit with all. I was asked to do it again the following year and I did. I doubled the recipe and we still needed more. this is a time saver and is the most delicious gravy I've ever had.

I really like this and it was great to not have to worry if we would have enough from just the pan drippings. I added extra carrots but it made it a little sweet so I will stick with the original recipe. Mixed with gravy made from the pan drippings you couldn't really tell it was sweet. Definitely will make again!

I never got the brown bits after roasting the wings. Maybe they were too big. All that was rendered was juice. I did put the juice in a gravy separator, put the stock in the pot and used the fat with the flour for the rue. I used low sodium broth but it turned out bland. I would suggest using regular chicken broth. I did add salt to it for flavor. All in all, this is a good way to do it. I plan on making gravy the day of Thanksgiving. This is just really for leftovers because we never have any left.
I don't make gravy, my husband does! I used chicken drum sticks instead and this came out awesome! Hubby was very impressed. Keeping this on file for future uses!

Zip on the flavor. It needs celery salt, poultry seasoning and a whole heap of something. Very, very bland and does NOT taste like turkey gravy. I'll freeze it, then add some real gravy to it in hopes I didn't waste not only time but a lot of money for turkey wings, all for extra gravy.
Professional do not peel onions you are throwing away a ton of flavor
Made a great base. Being a picky chef, I still added fresh herbs, turkeys pan drippings, butter and a bit of cream before serving,
This didn’t work for me. It tasted like gravy from a fast food restaurant.

Instead of store bought I am making this recipe every time. I like that I can make my own but I am not stressed when the turkey is ready and I am still trying to get the gravy done. Delicious and fresh too!
A LOT of work and quite an added expense but well worth it! Tasted Rich and WONDERFUL!

I have made this gravy for a few years now and everyone loves it!! The recipe makes a generous amount and I love that the gravy ready to go on Thanksgiving Day. I use Turkey legs and wings - whatever I find at the store. Turkey parts can be difficult to find so I try to buy them early and stick them in the freezer. I add another onion, garlic, rosemary, sage, a couple of bay leaves and a dozen or so peppercorns to the pot. Enjoy!!
This is such a holiday staple now. I’ve used turkey legs and chicken wings as available with great results. Bones are good addition to turkey carcass for stock too.
Very good gravy but a little too much flour for us. I made as exactly written but the taste had a "doughy" flavor to it. Will try again but with only 1/2 cup flour.
Little challenging. Added Turkey drippings right before serving & everyone loved it

This will be my forever go-to recipe for making turkey gravy! The taste, aroma and viscosity are perfect - and best of all it’s ready to heat and serve on Thanksgiving. I used 4 large wings, one onion and a 1/2 dozen smashed cloves, all roasted for 1 1/2 hours to get the wings nice and golden brown. 

I made the rest of the recipe in my Instant Pot - cooking for 1 hour at high pressure and using natural pressure release (another 30 min). Since I’m serving two turkey breasts, they came with turkey gravy packets, which I added before whisking in the slurry of broth & flour. The only other deviation was adding a couple teaspoons of Maggi seasoning and a bit more salt. 

I ended up with two quarts of delicious, beautiful gravy for Thanksgiving. I’m sure this could be increased by adding more broth (I used 1 1/2 quarts), but it is perfect for our family, with enough for leftovers.

well.... I cut the recipe to serve 10, and that didn't come close to enough, so I suggest you stick with the 32, and if you have too much, oh well! It was too thick at first, so I put my wings back on to boil with some additional chicken broth and thinned the gravy. I added too much pepper, so thinned that with some lemon and sugar! VOILA! the gravy is delicious! My mother would be so proud! My small family gathering will love this gravy this year of covid 2020. Happy thanksgiving to all!

Wonderful gravy! I liked making it the day before thanksgiving. I placed the turkey wings directly on the roasting pan without the rack and had lots of yummy bits to add to the gravy. I made it exactly as the recipe was written. I will make this again.
This was really good . I did have to add some chicken base, then a bit of beef base to deepen the flavor.

This has been my go-to Holiday gravy for the past four years and I always receive complements on how great it is. This year I re-read the reviews and went with another reviewers recommendation of saving the fat that I skimmed off the top of the liquid after cooling, and made a roux with it. It gave the gravy a much richer taste.

This was amazing! What a stress reliever! I was so much calmer having the gravy prepared the day before. Heated up beautifully and everyone thought it was great. Only change I made was 3 turkey thighs instead of wings due to availability at the store. I would use turkey thighs again though I suppose wings would fit better in the stock pot.
My family makes this gravy every year for Thanksgiving. It is delicious and easy to make!
This was a really good recipe! The gravy is so tasty! I live in a small town with no butchers so I ended up using a 4lb turkey. Turned out great!

This recipe was a great find! I not only make it for the Holidays but also to have on hand for other meals as well. It tastes great and saves me from standing over a hot stove right before we set down to dinner. Whip some up for yourself, you won't be disappointed!

This recipe saves me every Thanksgiving! It’s fabulous, and I love that I can make it a couple weeks before and freeze. It’s almost impossible to mess up and consistently delicious. It saves me the gravy drama on Thanksgiving Day. Best recipe ever!
I have used this recipe for years! What I do differently is use smoked turkey wings and drums. This really takes the last minute stress off of your holiday meal

I made this with a deconstructed turkey removing the breast meat (used for ground turkey sausage). I also use turkey stock instead of chicken stock. This was just what we needed since we smoke our turkey on the Green Egg and don't end up with usable drippings. This is the perfect addition to our Thanksgiving menu.
This makes a delicious gravy. I would like to know how many servings it is. Also, I would cook in slightly covered. Thank you for posting this recipe.

We make our gravy a few weeks in advance every year - but I do it slightly differently... At the point in this recipe where the hot broth (gravy base) is strained, I then pour it into a few mason jars, seal the lids on, and put them outside to cool. We store the mason jars in the fridge till Thanksgiving. All of the fat rises to the top and separates from the broth. On Thanksgiving day, a few hours before the turkey comes out, I skim off the fat and pick up the recipe at that point with the butter and flour. It works perfect and the gravy is fresh. Regardless of how you make this, its important to realize that the amount of gravy you can make is limited by the amount of fat you have. Therefore its important to use as much fatty turkey (legs, wings) as possible. You are boiling the fat off of them to become the foundation for your gravy. If you boiled a lean cut of turkey, you'd have no fat to mix with the flour. If you want to increase the amount of turkey fat that you have when you are making the gravy, you can blend in a little extra butter to the flour. All in all, this is spectacular gravy and guests rave about it. You will look like a pro chef with this recipe.
Best recipe ever! My family says it's so good they could drink this gravy with straw.
Perfect!

I can't say enough good things about this gravy. It has taken the anxiety out of making the Thanksgiving gravy. I make it the night before and heat it up and add the flour right before dinner. It is so flavorful and you can make it any time. I added fresh rosemary and substitute fresh thyme for dried. I also added poultry seasonings. The flour ratio should be to your liking - add more flour for thicker, and in my opinion less flavorful, or less for a looser gravy. Perfection!
I also did a roux to add color, could have added browning sauce
The store got turkey necks instead of wings. So I used them for the initial stock and it was the best gravy I ever made. I always add two or three beef bullion cubes at the end to enhance the favor.
Perfect for when you are having deep fried turkey or needing to prepare in advance!
used wings and necks

The recipe is quite a bit of extra work, but it was nice not having to worry about the gravy on Thanksgiving. So if you have the time, I would recommend making it before hand. 

I couldn't find turkey wings, so I used two turkey thighs and three legs. I decided to do as some other reviewers had suggested and separate the fat and make a roux before adding the broth. I didn't feel like there was enough fat, so I added some bacon grease. I thought the final product was good but not great, although my guests really seemed to like it.

This is the 3rd or 4th time I made this recipe and it has been great. BUT this year I couldn't find turkey wings so I used turkey necks. Wow, the difference was very noticeable. Much more flavor. I chopped the necks into 2 or 3 pieces to really get the flavor out. I will be using necks from now on.

Turkey has always made me panic weeks before Thanksgiving because I never had enough drippings from the turkey to make a decent amount of gravy. This recipe allowed me to make as much as I needed prior to Thanksgiving so I didn't have to worry and make gravy last-minute after the turkey was done. It was GREAT!!
Making this gravy a day or two ahead of the big day, has made getting everything on the table at the last minute, while still hot, a breeze the last two years!

Love that I can make this ahead without having to wait for turkey drippings on Thanksgiving day. However it adds the cost of 6 turkey wings. They're $4 per lb in our area and they were $10 for the wings alone. That is fine since it takes some stress out on the big day. The problem is the recipe turned out really thick. I could have cut the flour in half. And that's what I will do next year. It was tasty though. The house smelled like turkey the day before Thanksgiving after making the gravy.

I made this and took the advice of another reviewer and used chicken for the drippings. It was delicious! It held up well and I made it two days prior. When I re-heated it, I added turkey drippings as well. I will definitely use this again!
Not impressed with this one. It could have had a stronger chicken flavor.

I make this every Thanksgiving but with a few changes. I do 6 Wings, package of necks, and giblets from turkey. Then after meat is baked I add all meat to stock and boil for 2 hours. Then I also add additional drippings from turkey next day, and add roux.

This turned out really well. I did make a few changes, based on what I had on hand.
I couldn't find turkey wings, so used a 3-pack of turkey drumsticks. I didn't have any carrots, so substituted celery.
Added 1.5 cups white wine instead of the water.
Added more seasoning (thyme, sage, Goya Adobo).
Definitely a keeper!

As has been mentioned several times, separate the fat to make a roux (you will need additional fat) for a proper thickening agent. I also added the wing meat back in. Tastes great and easy to make. Now if only turkey wings were a bit cheaper. LOL.

This is the best gravy I’ve ever had. I love the convenience of making it in advance. We didn’t find turkey wings, so I bought chicken wings. When all was said and done, we ate the chicken meat for dinner that night, saving the gravy for Thanksgiving.

Next time I’ll make twice as much. Yum!
Easy and tasty

I could cry this gravy is sooo good. I'm not a gravy maker and was very shocked when it came out so wonderful. You can't believe how many bad gravies I have made for Thanksgiving, until doing this one. Thank you for sharing this!!!!!
 It's worth every moment in preparation.
I heated the flour and chicken broth before adding to stockpot

genius! Make a week in advance and freeze! As others mention I use the drippings to make my roux, and add soy sauce instead of salt. Also used zaatar seasoning for the gravy. I heat it from thawed in a crock pot and adjust the thickness and seasonings right before serving.

i've made this gravy several times. It is great. Costly and time consuming, but well worth it.
Best gravy ever

I have made this for 2 years now for a large family dinner. BIG HIT! I never have been a good gravy maker and this recipe changed that! I make 1 1/2 recipes and have just enough left for some reheating .
I have made this gravy three times, and I will never go back to mixes or hit-or-miss homemade gravy. This takes some time, but it is easy and reliable and delicious.
Does this really make 32 servings?
Perfect! Takes a little time, but it is worth it!

Just made this for the 4th time. It is exceptional, everyone has raved about it. I did however, make the mistake of slicing the onions and they were burnt when I took the pan out of the oven. Make sure to quarter them.
So easy and very tasty, this will be my go to gravy recipe from now on!
Only change for me is substituting corn starch for the flour to avoid any flour tase. I've probably made this 10 or so times to date. Give it a try and good luck.
I have made this and will MAKE IT AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN.. Ten stars if we could.
This recipe was awful. It tasted like nothing but flour. I even added some of the Thanksgiving Day turkey drippings, and there was no recovering the gravy.

I made this gravy two days before Thanksgiving. It was the easiest gravy I have EVER made, and it tasted great! I have some in my family who are gluten free, so next time I will try it with a tapioca starch to see how it works
Great
great recipe! well worth the effort!

This was great to make while baking pies! I added fresh garlic and herbs for roasting and celery for simmering. It tasted amazing! I stored it in a metal pitcher so all I had to do to reheat was put it in a pan of hot water. Love it!

Very good and super convenient to make the day before. would make again but next time place the onions below the turkey wings when roasting. The onions burned and resulted in a gravy a bit too dark. Made the roux as some reviews suggested and preferred this method. Also adding turkey drippings the next day would make this a 5 star.

I made this recipe and I got so many compliments on it this past Thanksgiving. It took a while, but wow was it well worth it! And I had more than plenty to freeze for next year. This is a must try for any Thanksgiving fanatic.

I did season the turkey wings with some caribbean seasonings and I added the meat back into it after straining it and it kinda put it over the top in my opinion.
This gravy was a real hit with my family. Maybe a little fussy to make but well worth the effort!

I made this the week before Thanksgiving and it saved so much time on the day of. I made a roux of the flour and butter, equal amounts of 1/2 cup each then added the strained turkey broth. I seasoned according to my taste, adding a dash of garlic powder, and a touch extra salt, but not too much. Froze for one week. Upon defrosting, and reheating in a pan on the stove, it seemed a bit lumpy, but after stirring with a whisk for a minute or so it became silky smooth and was delicious. I cut this recipoe in half and still had enough. It was fun to make.
Best gravy ever. Definitely will make again.

This will now be my go to gravy to make. The gravy was so flavorful and tasty. I had trouble locating that many turkey wings, so I substituted turkey legs in with some of the turkey wings. By the time this broth cooked down and was made into gravy, a person didn't even need salt and pepper. My family raved about the gravy and making it a few days ahead was a time saver.
This was awesome, making it ahead made the meal all come together easier, will definately do it again next year
Great Flavor! worth the extra work!

I used the idea—my daughter was cooking the turkey at her house, but gave me the neck & giblets that I used to make broth. I roasted chicken thighs and neck with the vegetables. I also had a quart of my homemade chicken broth. I loved using the flour to make a roux. Then when we got to the house, I was able to get the drippings from the turkey pan to add in. It was great gravy!

I used this recipe for a guideline as I had to increase mine and I did add aromatics not given However, I followed the procedure and feel this is a good recipe. I will be using it again as everyone loved the gravy.

I have never been able to make a decent gravy. Saw this recipe, and Decided to give it a try. It is time consuming, the time of roasting and the time of cooking on the stove but it is all worth it and very easy. I got great reviews from my family they all loved it. It'll be on our table from now on. Thank you .
I have done this for the last 3 Thanksgiving Days . Need to make more each year

I used 3 turkey legs as that what was available. It came out perfectly. It was one more step I didn't need to do on Thanksgiving Day. I will do this every year now. I even have a little left over and will use it for Turkey Pot Pie.

This gravy was very good and saved a lot of time on Thanksgiving Day. I made it exactly as recipe said - except substituted one can turkey broth for two of the cups of water. Little seasoned salt too. Everyone (19 people) loved it. I’ll make it again.

Meh. Disappointing. Definitely missing something in the flavor department and also looked more like a dark beef gravy than a nice giblet gravy, due to using the roasted wings. It would have probably been improved by the addition of some aromatics - I would recommend fresh sage and rosemary. Next time I still with my standby recipe to make gravy on the day of using the neck and giblets, and a base of turkey fat and flour to thicken it when the turkey is done.

I tried this recipe and it was just delicious! We also enjoy having hot turkey sandwiches and we never had enough gravy or just enough that I had to add package gravy mix to make enough for the sandwiches. This recipe solves that problem!! Thank you for sharing!
Great gravy! Takes a bit of time to make but worth it. I will definitely make it again!
I decided to make the butter and flour in to a roux with the additional 2 cups of broth before adding it to the rest of the mixture. Came out great!
Very nice! Turned out very well!

Expensive to make. The 6 wings cost almost 30 dollars. I followed the instructions exactly. The broth tasted burnt and was not useable for Thanksgiving. I will keep and freeze it to add to soup at a later date. Would deffinately NOT make it again.

Excellent! I have always hated making the gravy when everything else is ready to go on the table! Here is the perfect solution and I doubled the recipe so I am certain I will have plenty on Thanksgiving. Would love to have hot turkey sandwiches over the weekend! I did NOT throw away the veggies after straining. After taking the meat off the wings, I added that meat and the strained veggies to another soup I was making. If I did not have a soup cooking on the stove I would save them, throw them in the freezer for use later on.
This came out tastier than the gravy I usually make with the full bird drippings!

WOULD NO+ CHANGE A +HING!
EXCELLEN+!
I got this recipe from a magazine years ago, and it is the only gravy that comes out perfectly. The only change I make? I use three turkey drumsticks. So good!

Way to much work for a gravy that can be made by using roasted giblets and wing tips from your turkey.

Also turkey backs are cheaper than wings and provide much more flavor.

I kind of mashed together this recipe with Chef John's and got a great result! Put celery, carrots and onion in the pan withe the wings. Used the chicken broth in this recipe, pureed some of the veg and added it to gravy, (after pressing) and made a roux. Turned out great, and will add pan drippings on T-day. One less thing to worry about!

I’m giving it a 4 because I made a few changes. Like others said, it is a lengthy process, but the end result is very good. I couldn’t get turkey wings, but my local supermarket had necks and backs. They worked perfectly. I also took the recommendation of others who said they used a combination of chicken broth and water. I simmered it for two hours and ended up with a wonderful broth. While making the gravy, I added in a jar of turkey gravy base by William Sonoma. It gave me the volume I needed for a large group and a richer color for the gravy. I didn’t add cayenne pepper, but did add herbs to the gravy. It was delicious, and it was done early!
